course_title: Masterclass- Advanced Research in the Humanities

learning_outcomes.description: Demonstrate an understanding of the basic principles of interdisciplinary research.

Be able to design relevant and feasible approaches to investigating research problems, including undertaking research at honours level, creating your own research questions, methodological approaches, and research designs.
Demonstrate knowledge of practical and theoretical issues underpinning work with Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people and communities.
Understand the types of discourses in which work with Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people is situated - both historically and today - and your own positioning to these.
Use library and electronic resources at a level appropriate for your research and be able to locate appropriate materials for your area of study.
Communicate and interact competently and professionally in an industry environment (using a range of communication methods).
Demonstrate your skills and strengths in various career development situations.

assessments.task_description:
Participation is essential for passing this course, and requires you to interact respectfully and learn from your peers. Students are expected to participate in seminar discussions and relevant seminar tasks. This assessment requires you to show evidence of preparation for seminars and participate in large and small group discussions with relevant and well-focused comments. Participation in non-compulsory activities is not essential, but will earn you additional points. 


The participation component is larger in this course than other humanities courses, because it includes participation and effectiveness in your Public Humanities mini-internship. Throughout this period you will fill out an internship reflective diary, and your internship line-manager will submit comments and feedback on your performance.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.

assessments.task_description: You should introduce 2-3 draft research questions in a BRIEF document (250 words in length, excluding bibliography), presenting a GENERAL area of study, a potential research approach, and an indicative bibliography (ca 3-5 sources) within the context of your preferred major. This is a research exercise, evaluating your skills, knowledge and approach in acquiring relevant research material - and it does not need to be related to your future honours plans. You will receive feedback on the level of sophistication of the formulation of your research questions in relation to your topic, sources and approach.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.due_date:
26/09/2025 2:00 pm

A schedule for the oral component will be released on 12/09/25 - students will sign up for a preferred 15-minute time slot.
assessments.category: Practical/ Demonstration, Portfolio, Role play/ Simulation
assessments.task_description:
You will be given a 15-minute time slot within a set of of exam times in weeks 10 and 11 to complete a mock-job interview in front of a panel of examiners, drawing on your recent mini-internship experiences, and your experience of the Advanced Humanities program as a whole.


You must also submit your current CV and a written 'Response to Selection Criteria' (500-750 words) via Turnitin by Friday 26/09/25 at 2pm.

The selection criteria and interview time slots will be released two weeks in advance, on Friday 12/09/25 at 2pm.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.due_date:
5/11/2025 2:00 pm

Essay plans should be approved in tutorials in week 13, or sent via email for approval at the latest on Friday 1/11/25 at 2pm.
assessments.task_description:
For this assignment, a feature story for the magazine Reconcilliation News, you should reflect EITHER on the research questions you constructed for the first assessment in the 'Research Trajectories' part of this course OR your mini-internship experience, in light of the encounters you've had and questions surrounding research ethics, cultural complexity, and allyship discussed in the 'Cultural Trajectories' part of the course. Your article should present a nuanced set of perspectives, reflecting on the historical, political, cultural and/or philosophical complexities underpinning your topic.


This assignment requires you to hand in an essay plan, developed and approved in class in week 13, including a framing story, core ethical considerations, and a list of preliminary secondary texts. You are encouraged to adopt a reflective writing style, contemplating why the topic peaked your interest and how it challenged your cultural, political and/or academic assumptions. You should also make use of appropriate secondary reading material from the course and/or acquired through independent study. This could include material from your home disciplines, alongside perspectives on Indigenous knowledges, respectful collaboration, reconcilliation, storying and/or other approaches studied throughout the course.


Your feature article should be ca 2,500 words in length, not including footnotes and bibliography, and should be formatted and referenced according to MLA style.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 1 Lecture: INTRODUCTION TO THE COURSE: The Future of Work, Humanities Research, and Cultural Collaboration

LECTURE: Introduction to interdisciplinary research, the differences and similarities between humanities disciplines, and the future work place.


INTERVIEWS: Mixed UQ HASS Staff


Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L05, L07
learning_activities.topic_title: Week 1 Lecture: INTRODUCTION TO THE COURSE: The Future of Work, Humanities Research, and Cultural Collaboration
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 1 Lecture: INTRODUCTION TO THE COURSE: The Future of Work, Humanities Research, and Cultural Collaboration LECTURE: Introduction to interdisciplinary research, the differences and similarities between humanities disciplines, and the future work place. INTERVIEWS: Mixed UQ HASS Staff

learning_activities.topic:
Week 2 Lecture: RESEARCH TRAJECTORIES: Finding Your Discipline, Your Focus, and Your Collaborators

LECTURE: This lecture will focus on how you may start to formulate a humanities research project, emphasising the importance of honing in and refining a topic. We will also discuss the mini-internships that form part of this course.


INTERVIEWS: Dr Mair Underwood & Jasmine Sandes


Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L05
learning_activities.topic_title: Week 2 Lecture: RESEARCH TRAJECTORIES: Finding Your Discipline, Your Focus, and Your Collaborators
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 2 Lecture: RESEARCH TRAJECTORIES: Finding Your Discipline, Your Focus, and Your Collaborators LECTURE: This lecture will focus on how you may start to formulate a humanities research project, emphasising the importance of honing in and refining a topic. We will also discuss the mini-internships that form part of this course. INTERVIEWS: Dr Mair Underwood & Jasmine Sandes

learning_activities.topic:
Week 2 Seminar

PRACTICAL WORKSHOP: We will discuss different disciplinary methodologies and start working in discipline-specific groups to start workshopping your preferred research areas. We will discuss how to contact potential research supervisors/collaborators, and how to negotiate a project with them. We will also workshop ways of formulating appropriate email conversations with other scholars, and you will be encouraged to consider your choice of mini-internship for the course.


REQUIRED READINGS: Eco and Bunda (through Blackboard)


Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L04, L05
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 2 Seminar PRACTICAL WORKSHOP: We will discuss different disciplinary methodologies and start working in discipline-specific groups to start workshopping your preferred research areas. We will discuss how to contact potential research supervisors/collaborators, and how to negotiate a project with them. We will also workshop ways of formulating appropriate email conversations with other scholars, and you will be encouraged to consider your choice of mini-internship for the course. REQUIRED READINGS: Eco and Bunda (through Blackboard)

learning_activities.topic:
Week 3 Lecture: RESEARCH TRAJECTORIES: Formulating the Right Questions

PRE-RECORDED LECTURE (due to Ekka Holiday): We will discuss how you go about communicating your research ideas clearly and efficiently when you first start formulating your ideas. We will focus on how to formulate the right research questions.


INTERVIEW: Professor Anna Johnston


Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L05
learning_activities.topic_title: Week 3 Lecture: RESEARCH TRAJECTORIES: Formulating the Right Questions
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 3 Lecture: RESEARCH TRAJECTORIES: Formulating the Right Questions PRE-RECORDED LECTURE (due to Ekka Holiday): We will discuss how you go about communicating your research ideas clearly and efficiently when you first start formulating your ideas. We will focus on how to formulate the right research questions. INTERVIEW: Professor Anna Johnston

learning_activities.topic:
Week 3 Seminar

PRACTICAL WORKSHOP: We will discuss and workshop ways of organising your research, and formulating your ideas into a set of productive research questions. You will also be encouraged to sign up for a mini-internship in class.


REQUIRED READING: Booth, Menken and Fredericks, through Blackboard.


Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L05
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 3 Seminar PRACTICAL WORKSHOP: We will discuss and workshop ways of organising your research, and formulating your ideas into a set of productive research questions. You will also be encouraged to sign up for a mini-internship in class. REQUIRED READING: Booth, Menken and Fredericks, through Blackboard.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 4 Lecture: RESEARCH TRAJECTORIES: Structuring Your Thinking

PRE-RECORDED LECTURE: This lecture will introduce practical skills on how you refine your research topic, and find your original research contribution, alongside a discussion of how research skills may be used in a variety of future career paths. We will also discuss UQ Research Culture, Practice, and Resources, emphasising time management.


INTERVIEW: Choose ONE interview among a selection of interviews with humanities graduates in different careers


Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L05
learning_activities.topic_title: Week 4 Lecture: RESEARCH TRAJECTORIES: Structuring Your Thinking

We will also discuss UQ Research Culture, Practice, and Resources, emphasising time management. INTERVIEW: Choose ONE interview among a selection of interviews with humanities graduates in different careers

learning_activities.topic:
Week 4 Seminar

PRACTICAL WORKSHOP: We will discuss practical work and research management skills, and you will complete a practical research exercise and a career trajectory exercise in class.


REQUIRED READING: Booth, Eco and Deloitte 2023, through Blackboard



Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L07

In this first lecture during your Public Humanities Mini-Internship, we will discuss how to make the most out of your internship period.


Learning outcomes: L06, L07

learning_activities.topic:
Week 6 Lecture: CULTURAL TRAJECTORIES: 'Storying' and Working with/for Indigenous People

This introductory lecture will primarily feature pre-recorded material this year, as Professor Tracey Bunda is on leave, but it will serve as an introduction to the UQ Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander content of this course, and will focus on the concept of 'storying' and the ethical mindset needed to conduct this work.


ATSIS GUEST SPEAKER: Professor Tracey Bunda


Learning outcomes: L03, L04, L06, L07

In this lecture, the award-winning Aboriginal author Anita Heiss will discuss protocols for recording and writing Indigenous stories: consultation processes and complexities.


Invited Guests: Professor Anita Heiss

learning_activities.topic:
Week 8 Lecture: WORK TRAJECTORIES: Education & Academia

In this lecture, you will get an introduction to what a career in education or academia may look like, from a representative from the UQ School of Education and a representative from the UQ Western Civ program. We will discuss the ways in which you could start such a journey - for example, the qualifications you need, and ways in which you can test if it suits you, and extra-curricular activities that may boost your CV.


Invited Guests: TBA (teachers and academics)


Learning outcomes: L06, L07

In this lecture, representatives from the UQ Art Museum will discuss what a career in museum, library and curatorial spaces may look like, and what you may need to do to get there.


Invited Guests: TBA (curators, librarians and people working in government)


Learning outcomes: L06, L07

learning_activities.topic:
Week 10 Lecture: CULTURAL TRAJECTORIES: Respect & Project Life Cycles

LECTURE/WORKSHOP WITH ATSIS: Jim Walker will discuss key considerations underpinning work with Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people and communities and consider project lifecycle issues, including, project planning, relationship building and consultation, project implementation, participation, project reporting, dissemination and ongoing relationships.


Guest Speaker: Jim Walker

Learning outcomes: L01, L03, L04, L05
learning_activities.topic_title: Week 10 Lecture: CULTURAL TRAJECTORIES: Respect & Project Life Cycles

Guest Speaker: Jim Walker

learning_activities.topic:
Week 10 Seminar

PRACTICAL SEMINARS: In our seminars we will discuss the difference between working 'with' and 'for' Indigenous people. We will also discuss 'Storying' as a methodology, and we will talk about ways in which we can use 'Storying' in our research.


REQUIRED READING: Bunda and 'Uluru Statement from the Heart'.


Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L07

We will also discuss 'Storying' as a methodology, and we will talk about ways in which we can use 'Storying' in our research. REQUIRED READING: Bunda and 'Uluru Statement from the Heart'.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 11 Lecture: CULTURAL TRAJECTORIES: Reciprocity

LECTURE/WORKSHOP WITH ATSIS: Professor Anne Pattel Gray will explore ideas of reciprocity, and the importance of developing strong relationships when working with Aboriginal people. She will also consider the ethics and issues surrounding research of the past.


Guest Speaker: Professor Anne Pattel Gray

She will also consider the ethics and issues surrounding research of the past. Guest Speaker: Professor Anne Pattel Gray

learning_activities.topic:
Week 11 Seminar

PRACTICAL SEMINARS: In our seminars, we will consider ways in which projects developed in collaboration with indigenous people may take shape, and discuss how to build a sustainable 'code' of ethics in research.


REQUIRED READING: Bunda and ATSIS 'Code of Ethics"


Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04

learning_activities.topic:
Week 12 Lecture: CULTURAL TRAJECTORIES: Locating Self & Ethical Questions

PRACTICAL LECTURE/WORKSHOP WITH ATSIS: Dr Coen Hird and A/Prof Steve Salisbury will discuss how they work together and also how they build and sustain relationships with Indigenous communities they work closely with.


Guest Speaker: Dr Coen Hird and Associate Professor Steve Salisbury

Learning outcomes: L01, L03, L04
learning_activities.topic_title: Week 12 Lecture: CULTURAL TRAJECTORIES: Locating Self & Ethical Questions

Guest Speaker: Dr Coen Hird and Associate Professor Steve Salisbury

learning_activities.topic:
Week 12 Seminar

PRACTICAL SEMINAR: In this workshop we will explore creative means of collaboration across cultural divides. We will also encourage you to consider your own cultural background and bias, and your position in relation to your indigenous collaborators, and we will discuss how to be a good ally.


REQUIRED READING: Bunda, Watego and Finlay.


Learning outcomes: L01, L03, L04, L05

We will also encourage you to consider your own cultural background and bias, and your position in relation to your indigenous collaborators, and we will discuss how to be a good ally. REQUIRED READING: Bunda, Watego and Finlay.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 13 Lecture: CULTURAL TRAJECTORIES: Writing for Reconciliation

This lecture will be devoted to the ethical questions and the impetus behind your final assessment of this course: an article for Reconciliation News.


Learning outcomes: L01, L03, L04, L05
